Fields.DialogueText: Captain, I feel we have gone far too long without discussing something very important.
Really? Is it something urgent?
It might not be urgent, but it's definitely something I should've brought up with you sooner. We haven't once talked about academia!
Honestly, Maury, we didn't really need to talk about it to know that you love education.
What was your first clue? My vast collection of books, my intelligence, my-
Actually it was-
Wait, you're distracting me! I came here wanting to know what you think about academics.
What do you mean?
Well, were you a good student? Did you like school? How were your grades? Tell me about your school life experience!

Fields.MenuText: I spent most of my time studying and getting good grades. I had high aspirations.
I wasn't really a fan of all the lessons. It was mostly just a place for me to fool around with my friends.
Let's just say I'm largely self-educated and leave it at that.

Fields.DialogueText: That sounds wonderful! I'm so glad you enjoyed your time at school and didn't squander it.
How could you not enjoy the lessons! That's the whole point! All that learning in one location. It's like an academic paradise!
Oh, were you one of those bad kids, Captain? Did you get in trouble for skipping school and stuff? You should be ashamed.
Does this have anything to do with the Morganas threat?
No. Honestly, I was just curious. You're a good Captain, and your time as a student is partly responsible for that.
Oh, that's kind of flattering.
Though you're not quite perfect. It might be time for some remedial lessons.
I don't like that look in your eyes.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Probably.
And yet I'm really not.
Actually, it was more that I didn't have much of a school to go to in the first place.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, no! Captain, that's terrible!
Hmm... How did this get so dirty? I swear, it's like it attracts dust.
Maury, what are you up to over there?
Oh, just a little bit of cleaning.
But cleaning what?
Oh, right, sorry, it's my brass sundial compass.
That's what that is. It's practically an antique.
I find it fascinating how people managed without modern advancements. I have collection of tools like these.

Fields.MenuText: Exactly how big is this collection of yours?
You're not using actually using that to navigate are you?
Maybe I'll keep an eye out for anything we could add to that collection.

Fields.DialogueText: Probably bigger than it should be. And growing.
Of course not! Not that I couldn't, mind you. I could use any of the tools in my collection in a pinch.
I'd really appreciate that!
Would you be interested in seeing my collection some time?
It sounds like quite the sight. How could I say no?
@BATTLE
Why is my office trashed? Is there such a thing as reverse robbery?!
Oh, here's the map. I take my eye off you for one second and you wind up under this pile of books.
Maury, is all of this your stuff?
Of course it's mine. It's obviously not yours, right?
Okay, but why is it all here? You have your own room. Why are you commandeering my office?
It's no big deal, Captain, I've just been feeling a little cluttered lately. I figured it'd be easier to organize everything in a smaller space.

Fields.MenuText: A smaller space? How big is your room?
You could've asked my permission first.
I don't care how cluttered you feel, you can't just take over my space.

Fields.DialogueText: You've been there, haven't you? Oh, I guess you might not have seen my closet.
But you could've said no. It's quicker if I just ask for forgiveness. It's the logical solution.
You're right. I'm sorry I took over your space. I just figured you'd want to help your Belle.
Can you please just do something about this mess?
Of course, Captain. The plan was to organize everything and move it back anyway.
I'm guessing I can't persuade you to take reverse the order of those two things?
What sense would that make? I just moved everything here.
@BATTLE
Look at that, everything is back in order. Actually, it might even be a little cleaner.
Well, I didn't just organize my stuff, I took the liberty to put some of your stuff in order too.
Well, I appreciate it, but let's not make this a common occurrence.
Hopefully it won't happen again. A cluttered environment leads to a cluttered mind, and I'd prefer to keep thinking straight.
I think we'd all prefer that. When will you be moving that last bit of stuff back to your room?
Actually, I was thinking I might leave a little bit of my things in here.
Why would you do that?
For productivity's sake. This way I'll have resources handy if I ever find myself in your office conversing with you.

Fields.MenuText: So what you mean is that you enjoy our conversations and you expect to have more of them?
Sounds like I'm just a big distraction to you.
But wouldn't they be distractions? Shouldn't your intellectual pursuits have your full attention?

Fields.DialogueText: You... I'm just... Shut up, don't get a big head or anything!
Sometimes maybe. But most of the time, you're pretty good at keeping me on track.
Oh, they get most of it. Talking to you requires very little of my focus.
You can go ahead and keep some of your stuff in here. Just not all of it!
Understood, Captain! Thanks.
@BATTLE
That's wasn't... okay, never mind.
Captain, I've been playing with an idea in my head for a while now.
What's this idea?
Well, you're aware of my prayer services that I provide for the crew.
I am.
I'd like to expand upon that.
What exactly do you mean? Are you asking to build a church or something? Because I don't think we have room.
No, obviously I'm not suggesting we build a church. I'm actually suggesting I start teaching lessons to the crew. Science lessons.

Fields.MenuText: You personally? How many balls are you looking to juggle?
From religion to science? That's a bit of a one eighty for most people.
You want to take my officers back to school? Don't you think we're all a little old for that?

Fields.DialogueText: I can handle it, Captain! This is important to me.
You already know how I feel about that subject, Captain.
You're never too old to learn. Though, as I understand it there are many people who, when they were younger, refused to learn.
I just feel like everyone could benefit from a better understanding of how the world works.
And I just don't feel like this is a priority.
Fine. I'll let this go for now. But I'll convince you one day, Captain.
@BATTLE
That's a fancy chart, Maury. Is there any reason it's taking over my desk?
I was just planning... Oh, sorry, am I in your way?
A little bit - but what are you planning?
Since I know the course we're taking, I've been monitoring and weather and currents.
If I stay alert, I might notice something we can use to get the upper hand on the Morganas in battle.
You do this a lot?
Of course. If I'm not looking for opportunities, then the Morganas most certainly will.

Fields.MenuText: You make a good point.
You really think the Morganas are that smart?
And do you see anything we could use?

Fields.DialogueText: Thanks for understanding. There are still those that don't treat the Morganas as the threat they are.
I don't know. And that's the problem.
Not yet, but when I do, you'll be the first to know.
Oh, but I can move somewhere else if I'm in your way.
No, it's fine, I can see you're in the middle of it. We can both use my desk.
Really? It's not the biggest desk.
You don't have to insult my desk when I'm trying to be nice here.
@BATTLE
Maury, does this look right to you?
Hmmm? Oh, sure. They seem fine.
Are you okay, Maury? You seem a little off.
You have a lot of friends, don't you, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: I wouldn't say a lot, but a good few.
Actually, I try not to make friends. Fewer people to betray you that way.
Tons. I try to make friends with everyone I meet.

Fields.DialogueText: A good few? Well, I just have a good one.
That's... a horrible way to think about it. You need friends, Captain. I at least have one, a really good one.
Yeah, you seem like the sort. I could never do that. I just count myself lucky to have one really good friend.
Who's this friend of yours?
USS Enterprise. The best friend a Belle could ask for.
The aircraft carrier? Yorktown class?
That's her! And I haven't had a chance to just talk to her in the longest time. I miss her.
Look, maybe we can arrange something. It's not like she's hard to find; it's just a matter of scheduling-
No, we shouldn't go out of our way just for me to see my friend. That would be-
*ALARM*
Morganas.
... Irresponsible. I was going to say that would be irresponsible. At least let me finish my sentence!
Come on, let's make them regret interrupting you.
@BATTLE
I'm on my way for the ship's daily prayer services, Captain.
Congratulations? Thank you for keeping me in the loop, I guess.
Perhaps I wasn't being clear. That was an invitation. This is where you thank me for the opportunity and come with me.
You want me to go pray with you?
That's right. In fact, you don't even have to pray if you don't want to. I've just noticed that you don't spend a lot of time with the rest of the crew.

Fields.MenuText: What can I say, I like my privacy.
That's just not true. I'm very involved.
Why would I go to your prayer service if I'm not praying?

Fields.DialogueText: You're the captain, you shouldn't close yourself off from the crew.
Do you now? All this involvement must happen while I'm sleeping then.
To grow closer to your crew. That's one of the duties of the captain.
Can you name even one officer on this ship?
As I thought, you need to- wait, the water.... We have Morganas inbound.
How are you so certain?
There's not enough time to explain. You just have to trust me.
Of course I trust you.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: ... There's one called Gary, right?
Burkett. Lee. Williams. Yang. McGovern. I can keep going.

Fields.DialogueText: First names?

Fields.MenuText: Really?
... I don't see how that's relevant.

Fields.DialogueText: I just think you need to- wait, the water.... We have Morganas inbound.
Impressive, Maury.
It wasn't that impressive. You've seen me take out stronger Morganas.
I meant knowing that they were coming. How'd you do that?
You know those charts I go over all the time?
On my desk? Yeah.
Well, I had already anticipated how the ocean was going to behave. When the current changed unexpectedly, that meant that something big was moving it.
How'd you know it was Morganas? It could've been a fleet, or... a big whale.
I risked it. If I was wrong, then the worst I'd have to do is apologize, but if my hunch was right and I said nothing... then whoever those Morganas attacked... I'd be to blame.

Fields.MenuText: You're not responsible for protecting everyone, Maury.
Better to ask forgiveness than permission? I get it.
It's too bad it wasn't a whale. I would've loved to see a huge whale!

Fields.DialogueText: I know. Logically that makes sense, but I still want to do everything I can.
I'm glad you understand. Permission can sometimes just get in the way. Ask any scientist.
That's the part you're focusing on? I swear, sometimes I think you're just a huge child, Captain.
Maury... I know you don't like the idea of the war, and the loss of lives... I promise I'll do everything I can to keep casualties to a minimum.
I appreciate it, Captain. But how about instead we just end the war really fast?
That too then.
@BATTLE
Captain, we have Morganas to the west. But that's not all...
What do you mean?
There's... Yeah, it's a civilian vessel. It's being attacked. The Morganas have it surrounded.
How many Morganas?
A lot. If it was just us, we could take them, but if we're concerned with keeping the civilians safe...

Fields.MenuText: We can't just leave them to die.
What do you think we should do, Maury?
They haven't seen us yet, right? Maybe we should stay out of this.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. We need to do something.
I think if we turn our backs on the, then we're leaving them to die.
You'd really be fine with leaving them to be consumed by the Morganas?
... We're going in. We just need to be careful. Let's get everyone out of this alive, Maury!
That's my captain!
@BATTLE
How's the ship doing, Maury?
We'll hold together. We're in better shape than that civilian ship we rescued.
And the crew?
As I said, we'll hold together. It was a tough choice, but you did the right thing, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: I know. I've just noticed a few upset glances in my direction.
It looks like some of the crew might disagree with you there.
If we had run we wouldn't have faced any casualties.

Fields.DialogueText: Their wounds are fresh. Give them some time to walk it off.
Don't pay them any mind. You're the captain. You need to make to hard decisions.
Maybe not today, but we'll still be facing the Morganas tomorrow.
I'm glad the civilians are still afloat, but I think I should give everyone some time to recover. I'll be in my quarters.
Is there anything I can do to help?
Just stay on lookout for any more threats.
@BATTLE
Hey, Captain, how are you doing in here?
I'm just fine. How's everything out there?
A little less interesting without you.
Tell that to these reports.  I'm neck-deep in paperwork and-
Oh, you're just sulking.
Excuse me?
It was a tough battle, and there were losses. But you know what a good friend of mine taught me? She told me that it's more important to celebrate the living.
Is that liquor?
Cachaça. The same thing I drank with Enterprise after she gave me that advice. Won't you share a drink with me?

Fields.MenuText: I'm not about to turn down free booze.
That's your advice? I didn't think you were the biggest fan of drinking.
Would you even take no for an answer?

Fields.DialogueText: I knew you wouldn't.
It can still be the solution to the problem, even if I don't like it.
I'll take that as a yes.
Come on, drink up. The Big E guarantees you'll feel better at the bottom of this bottle.
The Big E?
Enterprise's nickname. Maybe if I'll tell you about it after I drink a little more of this.
@BATTLE
You should be more concerned. If this happens again, who knows-
Stop. I've given you my answer. I think you're out of line. And now I'd like to get back to work.
This isn't over, Maury. I'm not just going to stay quiet.
I'm not asking you to be quiet. I'm asking you to be loud somewhere else. You're distracting me from my work.
Fine!
What was that about?
Oh, Captain... How much of that did you hear?
Just you telling him off. What'd he do to piss you off so bad?
Officer Hansen was... questioning you.
Oh, I'm... flattered. What do you mean though?
He's been very vocal about your decision to throw ourselves into that battle to save the civilian ship. He... lost a friend.

Fields.MenuText: I see... I understand how he feels.
That's no excuse to be insubordinate.
Dammit. I should go talk to him.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, it's unfortunate, but you're not to blame, the Morganas are.
Exactly what I keep telling him.
I suppose you can try, but I don't think he'll listen right now.
He might start causing issues with the crew. Anger has a habit of spreading.
We'll deal with that if and when it happens. For now, we'll just keep an eye on him.
@BATTLE
It's happened, Captain. Hansen is spreading his dissent. And it's making it impossible for me to read in peace.
That was quick. What's going on exactly?
He's so loud, he might as well screaming. I can hardly hear myself think.
Okay, I get it's hard for you to work, but I meant what's going on with the dissent spreading.
Oh, of course, obviously. He's gotten more members of the crew on his side. Most of them were injured or lost someone in the battle.

Fields.MenuText: If he has a problem with us putting ourselves in harm's way to protect civilians he doesn't understand the job.
Sounds like I'm gonna have to toss him overboard.
If it was this easy for everyone to turn on me, maybe I did do something wrong.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, I know.
That's your idea of a solution? If you actually did that you'd have a full on revolt on your hands.
Any competent captain would've made the same decision, Captain.
What we need to do is convince Hansen that he's wrong to blame you. The rest will follow.
Easier said than done. I've tried talking to the man, but all I get out of him is a glare and a "Yes, Captain, no, Captain, may I get back to my duties, Captain?"
*ALARM*
I'll think about that, but sounds like we've got trouble to deal with first.
@BATTLE
Captain, do you have time for a bit of a briefing?
A briefing during a meal? Can it wait until I'm finished?
Come on, Captain. If you're not doing at least two things at once, then you're wasting time.
Okay, then. What's this briefing for?
It's for dealing with Hansen. Our angry little potential mutineer.
Mutineer? You never said it was that serious.
I thought it was obvious. What else would his little group do? Go on strike?
... Go on. What's your plan?
We show him what it means to be in command. The weight of a choice like that, the pressure. Then he should be a little more understanding.

Fields.MenuText: Either I was focusing too much on chewing, or you still haven't really explained anything.
So we're giving him a promotion?
I like what I'm hearing. Tell me more.

Fields.DialogueText: I guess you're right. Sorry, in my mind, it's so clear.
Not quite. I'm not a fan of rewarding bad behavior. We're just going to give him a glimpse of what it's like in your shoes.
Glad to hear you're already on board.
We invite him to your office and give him a mock scenario similar to the one you were in. Of course, he won't know it's fake.
Make him think his choice will determine the fate of actual lives... Should be effective, if he buys it.
@BATTLE
Captain, I was told you wanted to speak with me. I was told it was urgent.
Urgent is right. We just received some time sensitive intelligence about the Morganas and... well, we still haven't acted on it.
Why haven't we acted on it? If it's really so time sensitive then we should already be doing something about it. Right?
It's not that simple. There are other factors. If we rush in there with everything we have then there's a good chance innocent people could be killed.
They have civilians? They've taken hostages.
It's unclear, but we know that amongst the gathered Morgana ships there's a handful of what look like merchant vessels in their midst.
We could go in with the intent of rescuing these ships, but there's a lot of Morganas between us and safety.
If we focus on saving the merchant ships, our chances of survival would be slim, to say the least.
This is still time sensitive information, right? So what's the order?
That's why I asked you here, Hansen. It hasn't escaped me what you've been saying around the ship.
Indeed. You've obviously been giving the question of how to balance risk a great deal of thought - we thought you might have some insight to bring to the table.
You... you want me to make the call?!

Fields.MenuText: It's not easy, I know. There are consequences to both decisions. Not to mention the troubled thoughts keeping you up at night.
Yes, and when you're making this choice, you can't make it lightly. Making decisions like this affects lives.
Yeah, and quickly. Minutes count here.

Fields.DialogueText: The troubled thoughts? There's no good decision here...
Either way we're facing losses. I can't make a call like this! I'm not the captain, you are!
I.... Either way we're facing losses. I can't make a call like this! I'm not the captain, you are!
We need a decision, Hansen. Time-sensitive, remember?
I... There's no way you can really expect me to make a decision like this!
Oh, look at that. Everyone's dead. Including us.
What...?
You're right. I wouldn't expect you to make a decision like this. It's my job to make hard choices like this test scenario.
Test scenario?
Never forget that everything you just felt, the fear and emotions running through your head, I feel that every day. And I'm still here.
I... think I understand. I was wrong.
Yes, you were. There's a reason our friend here is the captain. I'm glad you've learned your lesson.
@BATTLE
You haven't touched your meal, Captain. You're not still concerned about Hansen, are you?
Depends. Has the situation gotten any better with him?
Well, I can tell you I haven't been bothered by his tirades. I think our little talk really helped put things in perspective for him.
So he's not riling everyone up anymore? That's a good sign. Let's hope everyone takes the chance to cool down now.
Do you think something like this could happen again?

Fields.MenuText: It could. But I think we can handle it.
It's one of those things you always worry about as a captain. Your crew deciding you're not good enough to lead.
I'm more interested in what you think. Do you think we'll have more people like Hansen come forward?

Fields.DialogueText: I agree. Now that we've developed a solution that seems to work, it shouldn't be a problem.
You really worry about that? You shouldn't. You've proven you're a capable leader, Captain.
People will always have doubts. We'll just have to do our part to ease them.
You know, his situation could've gotten a lot worse without your help, Maury. Thank you.
Well, he shouldn't have interrupted my workflow.
Is that the only reason you helped?
You shouldn't ask questions you already know the answer to. Of course not.
@BATTLE
How are some people so frustratingly resistant to critique!?
Maury? You seem mad. I hope that anger isn't directed toward me.
It isn't. It's the other Belles. They refuse to listen to me.
Refuse to listen to you about what? Maybe you should start from the beginning.
None of the, seem at all interested in improving themselves. Well, I guess Enterprise listens to me sometimes, but none of the others.
I'm very perceptive, you know that. So sometimes I notice things that other Belles could change to improve. Only none of them seem to care!
Some people don't like being critiqued. And I get the feeling your approach might not exactly be gentle.
They're just refusing to learn. That doesn't make sense to me. If you never learn, then what's the point?

Fields.MenuText: Not everyone is as hungry for knowledge as you, Maury.
They might be more interested in what you have to say if you took a softer approach.
If their methods work for them, then why try to change anything?

Fields.DialogueText: They don't have to hunger for it. They just shouldn't be rejecting it. It makes them seem stupid.
A softer approach? This is a serious matter, Captain. I don't have time to make everyone cookies before I tell them what they're doing wrong.
Because they could be doing things better. This is war. We have to think about efficiency.
I take it you don't socialize with the other Belles very often.
Besides, Enterprise, no. I don't like how irresponsible some of the other Belles can be.
Irresponsible, you say? So what would you want to do about these irresponsible Belles?
I'd want to hold one on one classes with each of them and inform them on how they could improve as a Belle.
I'm not sure if that's the best way to make them listen any better.
@BATTLE
Captain, do you happen to have any paper and envelopes? Oh, and something to write with?!
I'm sure I do somewhere. And shouldn't you too?
Of course I should, but now that I'm about to write a letter to my friend, I can't seem to find anything I need!
I assume this friend is Enterprise?
Of course. I think Big E's the only person I'd take the time to write a letter for.
So when you talk about the other Belles frivolous, you don't mean Enterprise.
Well, she's not perfect, but she doesn't get on my nerves. She's an exception in that way.

Fields.MenuText: You two sound like really good friends.
Have you tried making friends with any of the other Belles?
It sounds like you admire her.

Fields.DialogueText: She understands me, Captain. We make a good team, on and off the battlefield.
Well, I guess I've tried. It's just not the same. Enterprise is the best friend I could ask for, and no one else could even come close.
I guess I do. She's a great friend. Sometimes we don't even have to say anything, and she still knows what I'm thinking.
Is she all about science and learning, like you are?
No, not nearly as much as I am. But she listens to me when I go on and on about things. Like you do.
You make it sound like she's tolerating you.
So are you saying you only tolerate me?
Of course not.
Exactly. Enterprise might not like science as much as I do, but she likes me.
How could she not? Here, a pen, paper, and an envelope. Everything you need to write your letter.
Do you have any more paper? It's been a while since I've talked with her. I think I'll have a lot to write.
@BATTLE
Oh, hey, Maury. I was just heading to out to get some food. Care to join me?
I'm not here for casual small talk, Captain. I'm here to issue a formal request.
Sounds important. What's going on?
The room we hold our religious services in. It's no longer large enough.
That's good news, right? It means more people are exploring their faith.
Of course, but without a larger room, I'm going to either have to start turning people away, or have everyone packed in like sardines.
Yeah, neither is an attractive option.
That's why we need a bigger space. That shouldn't be a problem. Right?

Fields.MenuText: It's no problem at all. I'll find somewhere larger for you to set up shop.
You know I'm not the biggest fan of your church services, but if you find an available room, I'm not going to stop you.
Do you really need a bigger space though? I mean, maybe the smaller space would encourage a feeling of closeness.

Fields.DialogueText: I'd really appreciate that, thank you. And not only me, but all the officers that attend.
I understand. I'll start looking for a room right away. I actually do have a few ideas already.
It could also encourage a feeling of claustrophobia.
There's actually something else I'd like to use the larger space for.
And that is?
*ALARM*
Something to help fight this Morgana threat.
I'd like to hear more about it later then. For now, let's take care of the more imminent threat.
@BATTLE
The new space is prepared, Captain. You sure you don't want to join us for the first meeting there?
Wish I could, but someone has to keep this ship afloat.
You're always so busy.
Actually, before I go, Captain... I wanted to bring up something else I wanted to use the new space for.
What do you have in mind?
I mentioned this earlier, and you didn't seem to like the idea, but I want to hold classes for the crew.

Fields.MenuText: My crew aren't children, and you're not a schoolmarm.
I remember. You really think this is a good idea?
Hmmm... I think this could be a good idea. I know a few officers who could learn a thing or two.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not implying they are. I'd also teach some tactics and strategy on top of the science.
I do. Knowledge is best utilized when it's shared. And I have a lot to share.
Exactly. I'm glad you see things my way. It's surprising how little some people managed to learn in school.
Whether you had my permission or not, I'm guessing you'd go through with this.
Probably.
Well, good luck then. I'm not sure how you'll get their butts in the seats, but if you do, I'm sure they'll be better for it.
Your confidence in me means a lot, Captain.
@BATTLE
Deep breaths, Maury. Everything is fine. Nothing to worry about.
Those sound like some famous last words.
I don't foresee dying anytime soon. My stomach is simply tied up in knots. It's textbook anxiety. I'm nervous.
You? Nervous? About what?
I'm about to teach my first lesson to the crew. From what I've read about anxiety, I assume that must be the cause.

Fields.MenuText: From what you've read? You're talking like you've never gotten anxious before.
You actually got butts in the seats? What are you worried about then? I figured that'd be the hard part.
There's still time to turn back? You could just cancel this class if you don't think you can handle it.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm sure I have, just not this much. My stomach feels like it's learning to crochet with my intestines.
It wasn't as hard as you might think. The crew knows how intelligent I am. It's no wonder they want to learn from me.
I can handle it. I'm not letting something so inconsequential keep my class from the pursuit of knowledge.
You're going to be fine. You've got this. Honestly I'm more worried for everyone attending your class.
What do you mean? You don't think I'll make an excellent teacher?
Hmmm... just try and keep the lesson plan basic at first. No need to start with rocket science.
Of course not. Not on the first day. It'll be quite some time before we reach something so advanced.
@BATTLE
Maury, how was your class? Were you able to teach the crew something or are they a hopeless cause?
It was... It couldn't have gone better, Captain! Everyone was so ready to learn. I'm not sure I've ever been so proud.
That's fantastic. So why do you look so pale?
I may be a little drained. We have an excellent crew, but there are many officers who don't have an affinity for science.

Fields.MenuText: Sounds like you have some work to do.
If it was me, I'd have already given up.
It kinda sounds like you're calling them stupid.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, more work than I anticipated, but it's not hopeless. I think.
I find that hard to believe. I just can't picture you giving up on anyone.
They're not stupid. They're just smart in alternative ways.
What do you think about me sitting in on your next lesson?
I think that's a wonderful idea. I'm sure you could learn a lot too. And knowledge is power.
And we'll need all the power we can get to defeat the Morganas.
@BATTLE
No, I should wait a few weeks before I try teaching that... Maybe a little chemistry would make a good palate cleanser.
I've never heard chemistry described as a palate cleanser before. Makes sense though, coming from you.
Oh, hello, Captain. I was just working on my lesson plan. Teaching is more work than I first thought.
I don't know what made you think it was going to be easy.
Ms. Maury, I was hoping I might have a chance t sit down and talk to you about the previous lesson.
Ms. Maury? You make them call you that?
Actually we started that on our own.
I didn't like it at first, but I'm starting to warm up to it.

Fields.MenuText: How are you liking the class, Hansen?
I haven't seen you in a bit, Hansen. I trust you're not making any more trouble?
Who are you again?

Fields.DialogueText: Maury is a fantastic teacher. Her lessons really explain how important all of this is to know. For the war effort.
Of course not, Captain. I'm sorry again about that. I was just angry. And grieving.
I'm... Hansen. I was, kind of outspoken after losing my friend...
What did you need, Hansen? I am a little busy here.
Oh, it was just-
*ALARM*
Looks like you're going to need to talk to Ms. Maury later. We need her to destroy some Morganas.
Never any rest. Come find me later.
Yes, ma'am.
@BATTLE
Maury, somebody's got mail.
Mail? Did Enterprise write me back?
Do you know anyone else that signs with one big E?
That's her. I can wait to read it. And I already can't wait to write my next letter to her. I have so much to tell her.

Fields.MenuText: Make sure to tell her how awesome I am.
Let her know how much your classes are helping the crew.
Did you tell her about our little near mutiny?

Fields.DialogueText: You're not exactly the focus of conversation, Captain. The world doesn't revolve around you.
Exactly what I was thinking. We've been working like a well oiled machine since I started teaching everyone.
I may have mentioned something about it. I also mentioned we took care of it handily.
Right. I'll leave you alone so you can read your best friend's letter.
Best and only.
Well, you know that's not true. We're friends.
I.... Well, I didn't want to assume.
At this point in our relationship, Maury, it's less of an assumption and more of an obvious fact.
You're right. I'm glad we're friends, Captain.
So am I, Maury. Now go on and tear that letter open. I know you want to.
